I'll recommend this mostly if you like retro FPS or you want to see for yourself an important piece of video game history. In my opinion the right way to play this game is using the half-baked software renderer in a low resolution, the whole game gets a much tighter feel and ambience.

Unlike many of the older FPS games, the way half-life tries to be fun is not in the killing itself, but in its elaborate set pieces, which makes this game share more with Duke Nukem 3D than the Quake it inherited its engine. The most shocking thing to be found here is the ammount of levels that served as inspiration - or have been outright stolen - by the games that followed it.

It's a very cartoon nerdy game, the story is told by characters in game without cutscenes and without subtitles, which was rather new at the time. But even today that isn't too common, for good reason, because you might miss or mishear certain bit. The level design is a lot more fun once you've played it a first time, because there are parts that appear to intently be opaque as all hell.

The enemies don't get more interesting than the human soldiers where Valve did put a lot of effort into the AI. Either aliens, machines or human enemies they all feel rather bullet spongy, and the shotgun just doesn't pack enough damage or a clear enough spread to be a good weapon. Seriously, this game can take a lot of the blame for the death and disappearance of shotguns in FPS for a long time. Oh, and beware, this game ends with an old school really poorly aged floating and horrid boss battle.
